body:
@takraj Revisiting this pull request in light of the Database Adapter migration, I think it is best to close this for now and consider revisiting in the future.

Migrating Parameter Provider properties seems like less of a concern, since it is a more specialized feature, and the database-backed implementation is also a less-common use case. The change for Database Adapters could move forward independent of this change, so I recommend focusing there before coming back to this, and also getting something to a working state before reopening.

@rahulsharma980 Given that this applies to a Processor that is now deprecated and removed from the main branch, it is not a primary focus at this time. If you are able to resolve the automated build failures with correct tests, we could reconsider this pull request. It is possible to run the GitHub actions in your fork, so I recommend getting a clean build there before opening the pull request again.

@joewitt I've created [a Jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13662) but the work is not quite ready for review yet.   Do you want me to close this PR and reopen once the 2.x PR is ready, or is having the Jira good enough for tracking purposes? I'm fine with either approach. I should have the 2.x PR open very soon.

The key is new feature work should be going to 2x then as desired and review cycles available backported to 1.x. UI cases admittedly tougher.

We should not be introducing capability to 1.x then maybe eventually 2.x though.
@joewitt Alright, I'll close this and pursue opening the same feature for 2.x for now.
Will review...

Thanks for the feedback @dan-s1. I pushed a change adjusting the formatting. I also changed the headers building process to use the CRLF variable directly, instead of having it appended to the header lines.
I looked at the differences, file sizes for NARs remain the same and there are no new dependencies, just upgrades of existing ones
+1 LGTM, thanks for the upgrade! Merging to support/nifi-1.x and main
I will investigate a single previous event ID, hopefully that will be good enough for lineage purposes.
Will review...
Thanks for the update will merge once CI completes.
+1 LGTM, thanks for the fix! Merging to main. The backport is non-trivial, so if you'd like it backported please file a new PR if you haven't already
Thanks for applying the comments, +1 from my side, merging...
@mattyb149 Applied the change to 1.X
+1 LGTM, thanks for the doc! Merging to support/nifi-1.x
@mcgilman Sorry the pinging again. Just want to make sure this doesn't fall through the cracks.

> Thank you for the pull request. This is really an useful feature, which will provide more insight of the status of the C2 operation when an error happens.
> 
> I left some comments, please check them. Also two general comments:
> 
> * we should also apply this approach for all the the handlers, not just UpdateConfigurationOperationHandler. To use this approach properly, potentially some refactoring will be needed on handler level and below. For example, in UpdateAssetOperation handler the exception is logged, an optional is returned only. We should move away from the optional approach in favor of exception managed approach like in UpdateConfigurationOperationHandler.
> * Please squash the commits. Before the final review, there should only be one commit

Thanks you for the review. I applied the recommended changes and squashed the commits.

Hi @exceptionfactory !

For full disclosure, it looks like there is already an ordering within the mapping process: [here](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/7ade77ac22fc2e5bbd38151e32c96667020f30a8/nifi-commons/nifi-security-identity/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/authorization/util/IdentityMappingUtil.java#L125)

I take a looks of the usages and it seems to me that not all usages of the method is based (directly) on the result of the `getMapping` ([example](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/83b701a25ea2820d20768ca4946f5698249beb0a/nifi-registry/nifi-registry-core/nifi-registry-web-api/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/registry/web/security/authentication/IdentityAuthenticationProvider.java#L92), so I could not safely say that the original ordering is enough.

The question comes however if with this addition we still need the original ordering or not. I would not disturb it within this ticket but later on it might be a reasonable move to remove that (after considering the possible implications)

@exceptionfactory The code looks good to me. I am just struggling to understand where `MultipartFormDataStreamBuilder` and `StandardMultipartFormDataStreamBuilder` are actually used? I only see them being used in a unit test.

Thanks for the comments @dan-s1.

There is no initial use of the builder implementations, but the purpose of this pull request is to make it available for subsequent changes. The OkHttp library currently provides some Multipart Form Data handling, so direct support in `nifi-web-client-api` enables potential for additional refactoring away from OkHttp dependencies.
Changes look good +1
+1 LGTM, verified the expected behavior with PutIceberg. Thanks for the new feature! Merging to main
+1 LGTM, verified the changes and the behavior is as expected. Thanks for the new feature! Merging to main

Thanks for following up @simonbence. That's a good point about values already being sorted. The other reference you noted is for NiFi Registry, which is a different class. With the existing sorting, have you traced down where the sorting is not being applied on NiFi itself? It would seem to render the current set of changes unnecessary.

@exceptionfactory Per the Javadocs on [DateTimeFormatter.getResolverFields()](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html#getResolverFields--)

> This returns the resolver fields, used during the second phase of parsing when fields are resolved into dates and times. 
> By default, a formatter has no resolver fields, and thus returns null

Trying to use this before any parsing returns null which is where I need to use it in `ObjectZonedDateTimeConverter`

> @exceptionfactory Per the Javadocs on [DateTimeFormatter.getResolverFields()](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html#getResolverFields--)
> 
> > This returns the resolver fields, used during the second phase of parsing when fields are resolved into dates and times.
> > By default, a formatter has no resolver fields, and thus returns null
> 
> Trying to use this before any parsing returns null which is where I need to use it in `ObjectZonedDateTimeConverter`

Thanks for the reply, good point, sounds like another approach is needed.
@exceptionfactory Could I just relax the regular expression to look for timezone characters any place within the timestamp pattern?

> @exceptionfactory Could I just relax the regular expression to look for timezone characters any place within the timestamp pattern?

That's possible, although the characters could be escaped with single quotes, so the pattern would need some additional precision.
@exceptionfactory The regular expression is only looking for any of those single characters and I could relax  it not to be specifically at the end.

> @exceptionfactory The regular expression is only looking for any of those single characters and I could relax it not to be specifically at the end.

The pattern would need to look for those characters, without a subsequent single-quote, using something like `[^']?`.
@exceptionfactory Any ideas why the unit test I added failed on the JP and FR boxes? I suspect it has to do with the Timezone although I am not sure why my resetting of the Timezone did not work.

> @exceptionfactory Any ideas why the unit test I added failed on the JP and FR boxes? I suspect it has to do with the Timezone although I am not sure why my resetting of the Timezone did not work.

Yes, overriding the time zone in a particular unit test method is not a reliable solution for testing, and the failures point to a different approach needed. This is part of the reason for each workflow running in different time zones, as it surfaces time zone specific assumptions.

Instead of attempting to set the time zone, the expected values need to be constructed in a way that the resolved values matched the expected values.

> @mcgilman Sorry the pinging again. Just want to make sure this doesn't fall through the cracks.

I just pulled down the latest. After rebasing against current `main` there were build failures due to changes that have landed after your PR was created. So I tried to run the PR as-is without rebasing and I'm still seeing issues. When running through the dev server it fails to serve with

> Application bundle generation failed. [13.461 seconds]
> 
> ✘ [ERROR] Undefined function.
>     ╷
> 109 │ $surface-light-palette: mat.define-palette($surface-palette, 600, 100, 900);
>     │                         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
>     ╵
>   libs/shared/src/assets/themes/supplemental.scss 109:25  @import
>   apps/nifi/src/styles.scss 62:9                          root stylesheet [plugin angular-sass]
> 
>     angular:styles/global:styles:1:8:
>       1 │ @import 'apps/nifi/src/styles.scss';

I then tried running with the built application but I'm seeing this error in dev tools when attempting to open the `MoveControllerService` Component.

```
TypeError: g is not iterable
    at chunk-VIZEOFFB.js:70:66450
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at o.loadChildOptions (chunk-VIZEOFFB.js:70:66333)
    at new o (chunk-VIZEOFFB.js:70:65423)
    at o.ɵfac [as factory] (chunk-VIZEOFFB.js:70:67428)
    at hn (chunk-ZKVQE3GD.js:7:23746)
    at TC (chunk-ZKVQE3GD.js:7:63202)
    at mn.create (chunk-ZKVQE3GD.js:7:61795)
    at Vg.createComponent (chunk-ZKVQE3GD.js:7:64954)
    at t.attachComponentPortal (chunk-6XYXU2WR.js:1:110675)
```
Once the PR is updated I should be able to get some more eyes on it quickly.
@mcgilman I fixed the issue caused by rebasing and pushed. Thank You!

> Thanks for working on this improvement @juldrixx, I noted one general concern about the introduction of commons-lang3.

I'm not sure what is the change requested? And what is your concern? @exceptionfactory

> > Thanks for working on this improvement @juldrixx, I noted one general concern about the introduction of commons-lang3.
> 
> I'm not sure what is the change requested? And what is your concern? @exceptionfactory

@juldrixx Sorry about that, it looks like my code-level comment did not come through.

The concern there is introducing the commons-lang3 dependency just for the use of the `Triple` class. I recommend create a `record` that can be used to hold the values, avoiding the need for the commons-lang3 dependency.

> > > Thanks for working on this improvement @juldrixx, I noted one general concern about the introduction of commons-lang3.
> > 
> > 
> > I'm not sure what is the change requested? And what is your concern? @exceptionfactory
> 
> @juldrixx Sorry about that, it looks like my code-level comment did not come through.
> 
> The concern there is introducing the commons-lang3 dependency just for the use of the `Triple` class. I recommend create a `record` that can be used to hold the values, avoiding the need for the commons-lang3 dependency.

Should be good now @exceptionfactory, I reproduced what was done for `Tuple` but for `Triple`.
@exceptionfactory done!
system test failure appears unrelated to this change and is not a new spurious failure
Merged in https://github.com/apache/nifi/commit/8bdafb58c5ac930e795158b3cacabcceffba34c6
Merged in https://github.com/apache/nifi/commit/2f28354ff1c3ea133905341b621aed890727156c
Reviewing and testing
@dependabot ignore this major version
OK, I won't notify you about version 5.x.x again, unless you re-open this PR.

Will review...
Will review...

> There are merge conflicts here, I recommend not merging main into your feature branch but rather pulling down the latest main then checking out your feature branch and rebasing.

@mattyb149 I have resolved the conflict  and rebased .
Reviewing and testing...
Reviewing from a front-end perspective...

Thanks for the substantial work @mcgilman! I will review the server-side implementation soon.

I did notice a build failure related to a missing reference in `nifi-code-coverage`, so that should be removed for successful CI builds.
Rebased onto latest commit of `main` to resolve merge-issue due to [NIFI-13643](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13643) / #9163 affecting the same file.

Testing this out a bit.  Making great progress.

I tried a scenario with GenerateFlowFile to a python script.  The python script writes out flowfile content that is just "1.25.0".  The flowfile has only filename, path, and uuid attributes set.  I then route to updateAttribute that is stopped.  I then list queue and view content for one of these.  It shows up by default in a hex editor.  That looks good.  Then when I select view-text it shows a blank/white screen.  If I go back to hex editor it looks good.  Then back to text and it looks good.

So something funky there but perhaps related to flowfiles with minimal attributes.

Also notable in that same panel if I click around to csv it will sometimes give the white screen and sometimes render.
Thank you for the review & merge, @exceptionfactory.
@mcgilman I've completed the change/fixes requested. Thank You!

additional testing after a hard refresh the white screen i described still happens but it is very rare. in a local docker deployment it seems a bit easier to reproduce.  in local mode without docker it is very hard to reproduce.  it happened once in maybe 50 attempts.  

So in short - i dont think it is worth bothering with at this point.  might be a local issue/hard refresh certainly seems to have made the issue less likely.

thanks
Thanks for the review @exceptionfactory.  May I cherry-pick this into the support/nifi-1.x branch if it merges cleanly?

> Thanks for the review @exceptionfactory. May I cherry-pick this into the support/[nifi-1](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-1).x branch if it merges cleanly?

You're welcome @mosermw. This commit will not apply to the support branch because the Spring Configuration is now Java-based instead of XML-based, so adding it to the support branch would require a separate PR.

> > Thanks for the review @exceptionfactory. May I cherry-pick this into the support/[nifi-1](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-1).x branch if it merges cleanly?
> 
> You're welcome @mosermw. This commit will not apply to the support branch because the Spring Configuration is now Java-based instead of XML-based, so adding it to the support branch would require a separate PR.

Ah, right!  The nifi-framework-bundle moved, too.  At this point, I don't think a separate PR is worth it.
@mcgilman Sorry, I just realized my latest commit didn't go through. It's there now.

Rebased onto latest commit on `main` and refactored tests based on changes introduced in [NIFI-12852](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-12852) / #9198 affecting the same file.

I'd appreciate a review.

> Can we use the opportunity of this PR to also bump the bom version to 26.45.0?

Sure. That makes sense. Thanks for the heads-up!
Thank you for the review and taking on the merge process @pvillard31. 🙂

hi @mattyb149 
let me know if any thing need to be done form my side

@exceptionfactory thanks for the review! I refactored the approach so that the original `loadExtensionsUi(Set<Bundle>)` method now adds the bundles to a queue, and then a background task polls the queue to process the bundles, and the background task is not started until after Jetty has been started to avoid any issues with the Spring WebApplicationContext not being available yet.
Will review...
Closing the PR as it was not opened from my fork.

@exceptionfactory I actually implemented that way at first and had it working like that, but then I convinced myself that it wasn't really taking advantage of having a blocking queue and by polling the blocking queue we get almost immediate response when something is submitted, as opposed to waiting til the next time the scheduled task runs. Since the interval was only 5 seconds it doesn't really make a big difference so I can go back to the executor if you think it is cleaner. In that case it doesn't really poll the queue, it just calls drainTo to take everything at the time the task runs.

Thanks for the reply @bbende, that's a good point about the faster response time in the current approach.

That part sounds good. The only other change I would consider then is instantiating the Task in the declaration. That way it will never be `null`, just in case of an earlier startup failure.
@tydaljames please address merge conflicts with `main`, also follow the PR guidance by raising a jira ticket and referencing it in the commit message and PR title
Closing due to wrong ticket number in branch name and commit message.

I added one more commit for additional consistencies. I made "good bye" correctly a single word, "goodbye". Also, removed reference to the attribute "filename" which is not used or necessary in the given examples.

Thanks for the contribution @tydaljames. As Chris mentioned, please resolve the merge conflicts also create a Jira issue as indicated in the pull request checklist. Feel free to resubmit the pull request after going through those steps.
reviewing...

@maxpaynebupt Thanks for the contribution, however, this is an argument to the Dockerfile that can be passed as a build property. This version number is also updated during the release process, so it is not necessary to make changes right now.
Not sure why the MacOS build failed since it doesn't look related to documentation changes.
I apologize for losing track of this, but now there are merge conflicts. Once the conflicts are resolved I will finish the review and hopefully it is ready for merging.

Thanks for pointing out the `PythonProcessorIT` test suite @exceptionfactory, I added a separate test for checking the partitioning in 67288cda526ec205d85c1f607679fa9ceb3be48c
will review...

If it is too much effort we can skip it I think. Thanks again for the fix.
Merging.

> I apologize for losing track of this, but now there are merge conflicts. Once the conflicts are resolved I will finish the review and hopefully it is ready for merging.

Hi @mattyb149 
I have resolved the conflict please have a look

@joewitt This fix was inspired by the sample [here from Amazon](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/CopyingObjectsMPUapi.html). It seems like a boilerplate solution from their API, so how do we handle the L&N given the obvious influence on my PR?

@MikeThomsen One additional note, it would be more helpful to target this to the current main branch and then work on backporting the changes. Or are you planning to open a separate PR for the main branch?

> @joewitt This fix was inspired by the sample [here from Amazon](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/CopyingObjectsMPUapi.html). It seems like a boilerplate solution from their API, so how do we handle the L&N given the obvious influence on my PR?

If you copied code from somewhere else then you must know the LICENSE of that code you're copying, it must be category-A license (ALv2, MIT, etc..).  And it must be referenced in our NOTICE file for the impacted nar benefiting from the copied code, the top level NOTICE of our entire source tree, and the resulting NOTICE file of the assembly.  We have other such examples. 

Thanks
Will review...
